But first - review!

# Review

## Data Frames

`data.frame` - `R`'s _tabular_ data storage



::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
  Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species
1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa
2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa
3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa
```


:::
:::



## Data Frames

Key features: 

::: incremental

- Tabular (rows and columns) structure
- Entries in the same column are all of the same type
- Columns may be different types

::: 

## Data Frames

Can be manipulated using standard `R` syntax: 



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
table(iris[iris$Petal.Length > 5,"Species"])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

    setosa versicolor  virginica 
         0          1         41 
```


:::
:::



::: incremental 

- `$` extracts a column as a vector
- `name[row index, column index]`
  - Logical row indexing to select rows where Petal Length > 5
  - Column indexing by name to select a single column
  
:::

# Tidy Data

## What is Tidy Data?

"Tidy Data": Organizational principles to make data manipulation easy and safe

. . . 

"Best practices" 

Tidy data will *decrease chance of errors* and *increase productivity*

. . . 

What does it mean to be tidy? 

::: incremental

- **Everything in its proper place**

::: 

## Tidy Data



::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
  species bill_length_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g    sex
1  Adelie           39.1               181        3750   male
2  Adelie           39.5               186        3800 female
3  Adelie           40.3               195        3250 female
```


:::
:::



. . . 

Key features: 

::: incremental

- Each row is one observation (ðŸ§)
- Each column has _one and only one_ fact
- All values are in the table - not hiding in row and column names

:::

## Tidy Data

![](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/images/tidy-1.png)

> Figure from *`R` for Data Science* by H. Wickham

## Tidy Data - Why? 

Why emphasize tidy data? 

. . . 

Minimize distractions: 

- Free to focus on _analysis_ not _code_ 

. . . 

Once data is "tidy", you can focus on the real questions

"Tidying up" - goal of pre-processing 

## Tidy Data - Who (and When)?

The name and principles of "tidy data" were popularized by H. Wickham (2014)

. . . 

Core ideas are much older, dating back to (at least) Codd's *Relational Model*
in the 1970s, now ubiquitous in relational databases

. . . 

Now found in Python (`pandas`), Julia (`DataFrames`), Rust (`polars`) and more

## Tidy Data - How (and Where)?

`tidyverse` - Packages for Manipulating Tidy Data: 

::: incremental

- `ggplot2`: Visualization
- `dplyr`: `SQL`-like operations
- `tidyr`: Reshaping and cleaning data
- `readr`: Ingest tidy data into `R`
- `stringr`, `forcats`, `lubridate`: Tidy manipulation of different data types
- `tidymodels`: Tidy manipulation of statistical models

:::

. . . 

More helpers in the background (`tibble`, `vctrs`, ...)

## Some Untidy Examples

Baruch college business core enrollment:



::: {.cell}

:::

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 4
  Semester Course     Enrollment   Cap
  <chr>    <chr>           <dbl> <dbl>
1 Fall     Accounting        200   250
2 Fall     Law               100   125
3 Fall     Statistics        200   200
4 Spring   Accounting        300   350
5 Spring   Law                50   100
6 Spring   Statistics        400   400
```


:::
:::



## Some Untidy Examples

Multiple pieces of information in a single cell:



::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

1 Fall     Accounting "200 of 250"
2 Fall     Law        "100 of 125"
3 Fall     Statistics "200 of 200"
4 Spring   Accounting "300 of 350"
5 Spring   Law        " 50 of 100"
6 Spring   Statistics "400 of 400"
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
